_accidents.CI_OtherType: Removed bypass line, cut and capped. Forlifts no longer permitted in the room.

_exec_summary.SummaryText:
Accidental Release and Emergency Response Policies

Camino Real Foods is committed to providing a safe environment to its employees and surrounding communities.  This commitment is reflected in the safety and environmental programs that are implemented at the facility.  For example, written procedures have been created for operating the ammonia refrigeration system.  Only trained operators are permitted to perform system operations.  Camino Real Foods has also developed a robust maintenance program to ensure the equipment is in good operating condition.  All of these programs are geared towards the prevention of an accidental release at the facility.  In addition, these programs incorporate emergency procedures to mitigate the effects of a release if it does occur.  At such an event, emergency coordinators will assess the situation and notify outside responding agencies as necessary.



Stationary Source and Regulated Substance

Camino Real Foods is located at 2638 East Vernon Avenue in Vernon, California.  Ammonia is used in the facility's refrigeration system to provide cooling for freezer, cold storage and processing areas.  The system uses a maximum of 16,550 pounds of ammonia within four separate refrigeration systems.



A refrigeration system is a closed loop system that cycles ammonia through a series of equipment and valves, changing the pressure/temperature resulting in a phase change (liquid/gas) of the ammonia. The cycle begins at the storage vessel (high pressure receiver) where it will be sent directly to heat exchangers (process equipment, evaporators, etc.) or through an intermediary vessel (recirculator) where the pressure/temperature will be reduced prior to entering any remaining processing/cooling equipment. Within the processing/cooling equipment, the ammonia absorbs the heat from the surrounding air/product resulting in a change of phase (liquid to gas). This liquid/gas mixture is sent to the compressors (via accumulators) where the gas is incr

in place).  In addition, there have been no incidents at the facility in the last five years that resulted in a release of more than the Federal Reportable Quantity (100 pounds).



Emergency Response Program

Camino Real Foods has developed an Emergency Action Plan (EAP) for the purpose of protecting employees and the surrounding community.  The EAP covers procedures for: 1) evacuating and accounting for visitors and employees, 2) dealing with an ammonia release and other foreseeable emergencies that could occur onsite, 3) notifying external agencies and emergency response personnel, and 4) administering first aid measures for ammonia exposure.  Employees are informed of the elements of the EAP.  In the event of an ammonia release, employees will evacuate or shelter-in-place, depending on the nature of the release, and the facility will contact the fire department for assistance as necessary.

Planned Changes to Improve Safety



Process Hazard Analysis, Seismic Assessments and Compliance Audits have been performed on the ammonia refrigeration system, and these studies have resulted in action items to improve safety at the facility.  The recommendations mainly consist of formalizing procedures, implementing practices consistent with industry standards, and performing inspections and tests to maintain the integrity of the equipment.  Camino Real Foods has implemented several of these action items and is moving forward with completing the remaining outstanding recommendations.   In addition, the facility plans to continue providing employees with a safe work environment through continued training on current policies and procedures, and conducting audits to identify deficiencies and make improvements.



External Events

External events that could impact the operation of the ammonia system were discussed during the Hazard Review study.  Examples of events considered include various weather conditions, onsite and offsite fires, meteorite and missile impacts, theft, etc

.  The events examined, potential consequences, and the safety measures in place to reduce impacts are detailed in Table 2 below. The External Events Matrix was completed during the most recent PHA in April 2021. A seismic assessment was also performed by a licensed structural engineer, on the following systems and dates:



May 23, 2018

?    Main Refrigeration System

?    Mechanical Refrigeration System 1 & 2

?    Mechanical Refrigeration System 4



April 20, 2021

?    Mechanical Refrigeration System 3



The structural integrity of the ammonia system was evaluated following the "Guidance for CalARP Program Seismic Assessments" (prepared by the CalARP Program Seismic Guidance Committee, December 2013).  Recommendations were made during the inspection to install anchorage bolts and lateral restraints.  The facility is in the process of implementing these recommendations.  See the Seismic Assessment Report for further details.
